articles.headline: Indictment Presents Evidence Trump’s Actions Were More Blatant Than Known
articles.snippet: The accounts in the 49-page indictment provide compelling evidence of a shocking indifference toward some of the country’s most sensitive secrets.
articles.abstract: The accounts in the 49-page indictment provide compelling evidence of a shocking indifference toward some of the country’s most sensitive secrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The indictment of former President Donald J. Trump that was unsealed on Friday provided compelling evidence that Mr. Trump’s handling of classified documents was more cavalier, and his efforts to obstruct the government’s attempts to retrieve them more blatant, than previously known.
articles.byline: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: A Trump-Appointed Judge Who Showed Him Favor Gets the Documents Case
articles.snippet: The surprise assignment of Judge Aileen Cannon could be a setback for prosecutors as they unveiled a sweeping classified files indictment.
articles.abstract: The surprise assignment of Judge Aileen Cannon could be a setback for prosecutors as they unveiled a sweeping classified files indictment.
articles.lead_paragraph: Update: A court clerk has clarified that Judge Aileen M. Cannon was randomly selected for the case and will remain as judge.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage

articles.headline: Trump Put National Secrets at Risk, Prosecutors Say in Historic Indictment
articles.snippet: The indictment details evidence that the former president placed national security secrets in jeopardy and schemed to thwart the investigation into the matter.
articles.abstract: The indictment details evidence that the former president placed national security secrets in jeopardy and schemed to thwart the investigation into the matter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors laid out an evidence-packed case in an indictment unsealed on Friday that former President Donald J. Trump had put national security secrets at risk by mishandling classified documents he took from the White House and then schemed to block the government from reclaiming the material.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: As Ukraine Launches Counteroffensive, Definitions of ‘Success’ Vary
articles.snippet: Privately, U.S. and European officials concede that pushing all of Russia’s forces out of occupied Ukrainian land is highly unlikely.
articles.abstract: Privately, U.S. and European officials concede that pushing all of Russia’s forces out of occupied Ukrainian land is highly unlikely.
articles.lead_paragraph: After months of anticipation, Ukraine’s forces — newly trained on complex warfare tactics and armed with billions of dollars in sophisticated Western weaponry — launched operations on multiple fronts in the past week in an effort to dislodge entrenched Russian military units, a counteroffensive that many officials in the United States and Europe say could be a turning point in the 15-month war.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Trump’s Case Puts the Justice System on Trial, in a Test of Public Credibility
articles.snippet: The former president’s efforts to defend against multiple felony counts by discrediting law enforcement pose a grave challenge to democracy.
articles.abstract: The former president’s efforts to defend against multiple felony counts by discrediting law enforcement pose a grave challenge to democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump has a lot at stake in the federal criminal case lodged against him. He could, in theory, go to prison for years. But if he winds up in the dock in front of a jury, it is no exaggeration to suggest that American justice will be on trial as well.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Inside the Hunt for the Idaho Killer
articles.snippet: After four students were stabbed to death in a house near a college campus, investigators scooped up data and forensic evidence, hoping for leads. A new DNA technique finally brought a breakthrough.
articles.abstract: After four students were stabbed to death in a house near a college campus, investigators scooped up data and forensic evidence, hoping for leads. A new DNA technique finally brought a breakthrough.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the weeks after four University of Idaho students were found slaughtered in a house near campus last November, a growing roster of investigators desperately searching for answers had yet to identify a suspect or even find the murder weapon.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker

articles.headline: The Hottest Thing in Real Estate Is a Loan From Two Years Ago
articles.snippet: Real estate agents are pushing sub-3 percent mortgages as an amenity, just like marble countertops or a view of the mountains.
articles.abstract: Real estate agents are pushing sub-3 percent mortgages as an amenity, just like marble countertops or a view of the mountains.
articles.lead_paragraph: The only goal was to not lose money.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: From ‘Pariah’ to Partner, Saudi Leader Defies Threats to Isolate Him
articles.snippet: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has repeatedly leveraged Saudi Arabia’s wealth and influence to overcome international condemnation of the kingdom’s human rights violations.
articles.abstract: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman has repeatedly leveraged Saudi Arabia’s wealth and influence to overcome international condemnation of the kingdom’s human rights violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden vowed during his quest for the White House to make the Saudi crown prince, Mohammed bin Salman, a “pariah” over the killing and dismemberment of a dissident. He threatened the prince again last fall with “consequences” for defying American wishes on oil policy.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: With Probes of Russian Lines, Ukraine’s Counteroffensive Takes Shape
articles.snippet: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
articles.abstract: Ukraine is using its new arsenal of Western tanks and armored vehicles in what is expected to be one of the largest military operations in Europe since World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the south, Ukrainian soldiers are fighting on an unforgiving landscape, table-flat farmland with little cover for troops trying to advance.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: The Failed Affirmative Action Campaign That Shook Democrats
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court will soon rule on race-conscious college admissions, a core Democratic issue. But an analysis of a California referendum points to a divide between the party and voters.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court will soon rule on race-conscious college admissions, a core Democratic issue. But an analysis of a California referendum points to a divide between the party and voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2020 campaign to restore race-conscious affirmative action in California was close to gospel within the Democratic Party. It drew support from the governor, senators, state legislative leaders and a who’s who of business, nonprofit and labor elites, Black, Latino, white and Asian.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Ilana Marcus

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Confronts the Idea That the ‘Singularity’ Is Here
articles.snippet: The frenzy over artificial intelligence may be ushering in the long-awaited moment when technology goes wild. Or maybe it’s the hype that is out of control.
articles.abstract: The frenzy over artificial intelligence may be ushering in the long-awaited moment when technology goes wild. Or maybe it’s the hype that is out of control.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, Silicon Valley anticipated the moment when a new technology would come along and change everything. It would unite human and machine, probably for the better but possibly for the worse, and split history into before and after.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Faceless, Nameless and Dead by the Dozen in a Train’s Cheapest Cars
articles.snippet: In India’s worst railway disaster in decades, nearly all of the 288 dead were in three crowded cars where passengers stand for long stretches.
articles.abstract: In India’s worst railway disaster in decades, nearly all of the 288 dead were in three crowded cars where passengers stand for long stretches.
articles.lead_paragraph: They cram themselves every day by the millions onto India’s overtaxed trains, chasing a shred of economic opportunity across the vastness of the world’s most populous nation.
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir, Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: Trump Indictment Shows Critical Evidence Came From One of His Own Lawyers
articles.snippet: M. Evan Corcoran, who was hired to represent the former president after the Justice Department issued a subpoena for classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, could be a key witness in the trial.
articles.abstract: M. Evan Corcoran, who was hired to represent the former president after the Justice Department issued a subpoena for classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, could be a key witness in the trial.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates as Donald Trump is scheduled to be arraigned this afternoon in Miami.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Alan Feuer and Ben Protess

articles.headline: China Creates a Coast Guard Like No Other, Seeking Supremacy in Asian Seas
articles.snippet: Beijing’s patrol vessels often resemble warships. Now other nations are trying to compete with tougher coast guards of their own.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s patrol vessels often resemble warships. Now other nations are trying to compete with tougher coast guards of their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seeking to dominate the strategic waterways of Asia, China has deployed an armada of boats that are equipped with 76-millimeter cannons, the capacity to add anti-ship missiles, and they are bigger than U.S. Navy destroyers. But they are not Chinese Navy vessels. Their hulls are painted white, with “China Coast Guard” in block letters on the sides.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave

articles.headline: As the Fed Meets, It Shares an Inflation Problem With the World
articles.snippet: Inflation is stubborn across a range of economies. Given its staying power, investors expect the Fed to pause rate moves only temporarily.
articles.abstract: Inflation is stubborn across a range of economies. Given its staying power, investors expect the Fed to pause rate moves only temporarily.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday is expected to stop raising interest rates for the first time in 11 policy meetings. But investors are betting that the pause will not last.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: WeWork Faces More Turmoil After Its Chief Executive Departs
articles.snippet: The company’s top boss, a real estate industry veteran, abruptly left in May after growing frustrated with SoftBank, its largest shareholder and lender.
articles.abstract: The company’s top boss, a real estate industry veteran, abruptly left in May after growing frustrated with SoftBank, its largest shareholder and lender.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sandeep Mathrani was supposed to be WeWork’s savior.
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell and Peter Eavis

articles.headline: Fear and Mayhem as Russia’s War Comes Home
articles.snippet: Attacks from Ukraine have killed at least a dozen Russian civilians and displaced thousands. But they have not fundamentally changed the calculus for Vladimir Putin.
articles.abstract: Attacks from Ukraine have killed at least a dozen Russian civilians and displaced thousands. But they have not fundamentally changed the calculus for Vladimir Putin.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abandoned cats and dogs roam vacant streets lined with blasted apartment buildings, rubble and crumpled cars in Shebekino, a Russian border town pounded by shelling from Ukraine.
articles.byline: By Roger Cohen and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: Silvio Berlusconi, a Showman Who Upended Italian Politics and Culture, Dies at 86
articles.snippet: He introduced sex and glamour to Italian TV and then brought the same formula to politics, dominating the country and its culture for more than 20 years.
articles.abstract: He introduced sex and glamour to Italian TV and then brought the same formula to politics, dominating the country and its culture for more than 20 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Silvio Berlusconi, the brash media mogul who revolutionized Italian television using privately owned channels to become the country’s most polarizing and prosecuted prime minister over multiple stints in office and an often scandalous quarter-century of political and cultural influence, died on Monday at San Raffaele Hospital in Milan. He was 86.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Rachel Donadio

articles.headline: JPMorgan to Pay $290 Million in Settlement With Epstein’s Victims
articles.snippet: The proposed deal would settle a suit on behalf of victims who were sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein, over claims the bank ignored warnings about him.
articles.abstract: The proposed deal would settle a suit on behalf of victims who were sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein, over claims the bank ignored warnings about him.
articles.lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase reached a tentative settlement with sexual abuse victims of Jeffrey Epstein, the deceased financier, after weeks of embarrassing disclosures about the bank’s longstanding relationship with him, the bank and lawyers for the victims said in a statement on Monday.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Fox News Tells Tucker Carlson to Stop Posting Videos on Twitter
articles.snippet: The network and its former star host have been engaged in an increasingly bitter dispute over Mr. Carlson’s Twitter videos, which Fox says violate his contract.
articles.abstract: The network and its former star host have been engaged in an increasingly bitter dispute over Mr. Carlson’s Twitter videos, which Fox says violate his contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News has demanded that Tucker Carlson stop posting videos to Twitter, escalating the dispute between the network and its former star host over how — and if — he can continue to speak publicly now that his prime-time show is off the air.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Benjamin Mullin

articles.headline: Floridians Would Make Up Trump’s Jury Pool. Here’s What Some Are Saying.
articles.snippet: The complicated feelings among some residents about former President Donald J. Trump and the case against him reflect the complicated politics of the state.
articles.abstract: The complicated feelings among some residents about former President Donald J. Trump and the case against him reflect the complicated politics of the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow for live updates as Donald Trump is scheduled to be arraigned this afternoon in Miami.
articles.byline: By Nick Madigan, Verónica Zaragovia and Richard Fausset
